questionText: In 1997 at least 4.5 million families were paying more than 50% of their income on housing
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: Grants were made to non-profit organizations to build or rehabilitate apartments for the elderly and disabled.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: There is not enough low-cost housing in the United States.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: In 1995 there were 4.4 million more low-income earners than there were low-cost housing units.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Landlords were dropping out of rent subsidy programs to raise the rent or convert the real estate to condominiums.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: The number of homeless was rising.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Rents were going up faster than incomes.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: To address this crisis, various programs were used to create more low-cost housing.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Tax credits were created to encourage builders to build more units and build in low-income areas.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: The number of rent vouchers given to low-income city dwellers was increased.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: No new U.S. federal housing assistance vouchers were created after 1994.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Three-fifths of all poor renters spent more than halve their income on rent.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: In 1997 5.4 million were paying more than 50% of income for housing.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: In 1998, 90,000 new rent vouchers were created.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: There were two low-income renters for every low-cost unit.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: Three-fifths of all poor renters spent over half their income on rent.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: In 1998 there was a $283 million rent subsidy for 50,000 welfare job seekers.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: In 1998, with rising real estate prices, local governments built more low and moderate-income housing.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: The FY1999 housing budget provided $1.8 billion in new vouchers.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: Federal rent subsidies increased from 40% to 50% in 2000.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: The FY1999 housing budget provided $822 million for construction and rehabilitation of apartment unites and rent subsidies.
author: AI6U09NVOZ62B

questionText: The number of people living below the poverty level in America has increased.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: The amount of affordable housing for low and moderate-income residents has decreased.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: Republicans and Democrats disagree on how to increase low-cost housing.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: Republicans favored giving more subsidized rental units to the working poor.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: Democrats favored subsidizing housing for the poorest people in America.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: Democrats and Republicans had to compromise on a bill to address housing issues for low income people.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: Single mothers, elderly, immigrants and the working poor have the most trouble finding affordable housing.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: The working poor pay more than half their income for housing.
author: A2CCK1JKX48R0H

questionText: In America the number of people living below poverty level has increased.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Hardest hit are single mothers, elderly, immigrants and working poor.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Many owners of rental units now rent to higher income tenants.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Republicans wanted public housing to be available to all income groups.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Many state and local jurisdictions have creative programs to provide low-income housing.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: HUD will increase payments and provide other incentives to landlords.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Both Republicans and Democrats agreed there was a significant need for housing for low and moderate-income families.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Rises in housing costs were driven by a strong economy.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: Wages have not kept up with rises in housing costs.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: In 1977, banks were required to lend money to low-income and minority residents where they did business.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: Public housing turnover is low.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: Minority mortgage applicants face discrimination.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: Low-income Americans face problems in finding housing.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: The pool of affordable housing has shrunk.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Landlords have dropped out of subsidy programs.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Public housing concentrates extremely poor people.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: In 1977 banks were required to loan money to low-income and minority residents where they did business.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Real or proposed measures include block grants to states for housing assistance
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: It was proposed that FHA revenues be reserved for use in federal housing initiatives.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Congress refused any new assistance vouchers between 1995-1998.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y
